div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.

Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: THE MACEDONIAN TROUBLES.
div.p: The latest "Balletin d'Ocient" which we
Die i bave received from Atheds contains a gruee die some list of atrocities committed mainly at prach. the expense of Macedonian Greeks by bands
of Bulgarian Komitajis. We have no doubt An. that a similar pablication in Sofia would agell contain an equally long list of Greek outrages or in against Balgarians, while the Roomanian press
in is now committed, as is the Roomanian n in Government, to a farious anti-Hollonio camgiro, paigo. The irony of the whole situation lies
der in the fact that each of the Macedonian Co. c'aimants--Greece, Bulgaria, Sorvia, and Rog. naiz mania-aonounces that its programme is
des progressive and liberal. The Balgar and tho 4.60 Serviar, representing the Slavonic element sell-I in the Balkan States, aim at tha revival of Folg: the glories of Stopher or Simeon the Great.

The Rogmanian remembers Trajan and asserts that he is the lineal descendant of the Roman masters of the Balkan. The Greek claims nine-tenths of Macedonia in the name of the Byzantine Empire and the great Alexander, and also asserts that the race, which first founded Baropean civilisation and in later days preserved it for contaries against Exstern attack, deserves special consideration from thg civilised world whenever the fate of the unhappy province is finally settled.

In thg meantime esch of the candidates for the task of reconstruotion and civilisation wages an ansparing and atrocious wartare against his rivals. The Balgarian banda assail peacefat and harmless Moslems with the same forooity with which they murder oppressiveTarkish Beys or inconvenient Greek divinos. The Greeks, after announcing their moral superiority to the Balgariana, prey for another Basil Bulgaroktonos and descend on Balgarian and Kuteo Vlaoh' villages to murder and pillago. The - Roumanian Government, unable fr"geographical reasons to interfere in Macedonia, avenges the murdered Katz . . Viach, by expelling a few Greek agitatora and a multitude of peaceful merchants from ito borders, thereby both gratifying the mob a id relieving the native morohant of dangerous ommercial competitors.

Had the Ottoman Empire any of the sympatby with good government and progress that is asoribed to it by its unintelligent admirers it might have easily regained the confidence of its well-wishers by adopting a jnet and humane polioy towards the Rayaba and supported the Boropean chiofe of the gendarmerie who are doing their best, ander great difficulties, to check the acts of anoonsidered savagery committed sometimes by the Tarkish troops and at all times by the "Christian Patriots" of the province. Under the oiroumstances one fools inolined to hope for an eventual Acstrian occupation of the province. Russia is at present out of action and may long remain so; the events of tbo last two years have made the establishment of a Macedonian principality impossible, and under Austrian rule the vilayets of Kosove, Monastir, and Salonika might find some of the security that Bosnia and Herzegovina now opjoy.

div.head: DUELLING OVER A DOG.
div.p: Buda Pesth is confronted by the prospect of 150 challenges to as many duela having their origin in a kiok given to a dog. A sports man, named M. de Zombory, was on the Danube quay with bis dog, which go persistently annoyed a bank official, named S2000s, that the latter kioked it, and was then himself rated and struck by the owner. On receiving the seconds of M 820808 next day, M Zombory pleaded that a "gentleman like him" could peither apologise nor fight a mere bani clerk. This being reported at the bank, tho entire staff of 150 made 8znece's age their own, and sent seconds with such peremptory terme that conditions of meeting are now being arranged.

A few days ago & gang of thievea, of Kattoor, Gharbieh, broke into a cultivated field belonging to the omdeh of that village, and while rooting op ootton plants were discovered by the ghaffirg. Shots were exchanged between the two parties, one of the thieves and a ghaffir being killed.

Amin Ibrahim's New Role.

The novelty, recently introdaced by the Ra inanagement of Princes' Restaurant, Piccadilly, of having the famous Bgyptian, Amin Ibrahim, in native costame to serve Turkish coffee, bas, it seems, caught on. Mr. Colegrave (the Becretary of Princes') has received a special request to allow Amin Ibrahim to employ his coffee-making talents at a banquet at Norwich, to inaugurat ; tbe opening of the new offices of Pa the Norwich Union Life Insurance Society.

Half of this som has been handed Ger over to the French Consulate and the othered half to the Italian Consulate, to be romitted spe to the respective relief committees. The fêtes fon committee at Alexandria was dissolved yesterday. The members are to be congratulated on the gaccess which has crowned their philanthropio endeavours.
Successful Charity Concert !

The concert held at the Grand Continental seca Hotel, Cairo, on Saturday last was most sac- men cessfal, and the total receipts (P.T. 3,660) were ipoli daly banded over to the hon. treasurer of the Dich fand which is being raised in aid of the widow and children of the late Sergt-Major R. 8. an a Smith. We have been favoured with a copy the of the balance sheet signed by the president Pale and treasurer of the committee and are most be o pleased to notice that the expenses were abso- whic lately nil as by the generosity of those con- maic cerned no charge whatever was made; thos& te the widow has profited by every piastre deat subscribed. We are desired by the promoters date (the Ragheb Lodge of Cairo) to express their sincere and grateful thanks to all who have also 80 kindly given their help.

exten Information was given to the Press yester- thom day that a quarrel aroge on the 10th inst., Egyp between two families of the village of Naapiya of the and two families of the Ezbet el Dal el Kar, in the en the province of Meuoofieb, wbich resulted in a ship i general fight between the persons involved.stone, Daring the fight, in which twenty persons took | by big part, eight men ware severely injared. One of the men, statne however, separated himself from the general in go me!éo and attacked the proprietor of the ezbet, He wa who fired upon him with fatal results, the man Simon dyrug shortly afterwards. div.head: THE DENISHWAI OUTRAGE.
div.p: PREPARING FOR THE TRIAL.
No forther official news concerning the attack on British officers by the villagers of
Denishwai is forthcoming. As we reported on -iday.
Wednesday, the body of the late Captain Ball f in the

W88 exhumed the same day and an autopsy was held by Dr. Nolan, but the immediate cause of death has not yet been divulged. We have made enquiries in several quarters but we understand that no information will be given except that which can be derived from the evidence which will be given before the special
tribunal. The tribunal will commence its sittings School,
on Sunday morning at 10 o'clock and we are cate of
glad to be able to inform our readers that we on are :
have made every arrangement for a detailed Moba

who appear to have taken no part in the ! Abdel
affray were released on Wednesday.. amed,

officials to act as translators daring the trial.

district antil the trial is over. The ghaffirst ewfik

div.head: CAGE. THE PIGEON QUESTION.
div.p: ARE THEY THE PROPERTY OF THE
FELLAHEEN? ng the agers of | "Peregrinas" (Cairo) writes :- Since the orted on
terrible effsir at Denishwai became the topio sin Ball
of general conversation it has been possible psy was
to see that there is considerable ignorance Pange of
among foreigners, at any rate, on what might e bave becali
be called the pigeon question. but we
· Almost everyone imagines that the pigeons given
are the property of the fellabeen. This is not om the
the case. Pigeons in Egypt are of two species, special
which are known locally a9 (i) Bati and (ii). sittings Gebeli, or Borgi, or Beledi. The Beti pigeons we are
are the property of individuals; they are hat we
easily distinguished, as they are larger than etailed
the others, heavier on the wing, and almost 8 Bach
always parti-coloured. These Devergo far from ng the
the hats they live in and are too slow to show ading sport. The Gebeli are true Blue Rooks. We montros
may for present parposes igpore ornithological banal.
sub divisions. These birds, switt fliers and to be
small, are the birds one shoots when one can amber lín Egypt, bat almost everywhere the fellaheon others

div.head: LES SUCRERIES. : Da Progrés.
div.p: Da 18 septembre 1905 au 20 jain 1906, la déconfitare de la Société des Sucreries aura daré exactement neuf mois. Bien que la cause immédiate de la déconfitare et de la faillite qui s'engniyit de la Société ait été le suicide de Cronior et l'écroulement da système d'expé. dients qu'il personnifisit, nal ne donte aojourd'hai que le fonctionnement de la Société, tel qa'il existait 6008 l'ancien régime, devait. amener, tot on tard, le même résultat. A ce point de vue, à part les deuils et les pertes que la déconfitare de la Société a provoqué, nous Berions tentés de dire que cette crise a été salataire. Elle a eu l'effet da passage da fer brûlant da chirargien sur la plaie da malade. Certes, le malade en souffre, mais cette souf. france lui vaut la guérison.

Cependant. Ces réflexions ne justifient pas 17: à nos yeux le refas da concordat préventif. La faillite qui on est résultée et qui a abonti exactement au même résultat qu'on sollici. tait par le concordat préventif, & coûté, au bas, mot, cent mille livres au pays, aux créanciers, aux actionnaires. Ce fut une dernière bproave qu'on aurait dû épargner à la Société Nous le regrettons d'autant plus que cette épreuve & privé la Société da concours loyal d'hommes qui ont pu être victimes de lear bopté paturelle, mais dont personne n'a revoqué en doate l'boncêteté.

Tout cela appartient maintenant à l'histoire Si nous en parlons aujourd'hui, c'est parce que le souvenir des difficulté, passées doit 800tenir l'énergie des hommes nouveaux qui vont s'atteler à l'avre de longne baleine de la recopatraction financière et indastrielle de la Société. · Les noms séuls que nous avons publiés hier constitaent une garantie eure pour l'avenir. Harari Pacha, qui a été longtemps parmi les plas haats et les plus compétənts fonctionnai res de l'Etat et qui administre adjourd'hui aveo an si grand soocès le patrimoine élevé de la Daïra Sanjeh ; M. Raphael Saarès, le finan cier le plos correct et le plas autorisé de l'E. gypte ; Birch pache, dont on connait la compétence spéciale et l'influence sur les coltivateurs de la flagte:Egypte ; M. Naas, Boghos pacba cal Nabar, enfin, dont la nomination n'est p38 encore annoncée, mais dont le concours est aset goré, et qui va apporter à l'administration ac par taelle le prestige de son nom et de sa profonde der connaissance des intérêts réels du pays tous ces gentilshommes ne sont pas de natare à avoir accepté à la legère la tá zbe honorable, 1770 mais lourde de conserver au pays one indastrie gag dont il a besoin et de sauvegarder les intérêts considérables des actionnaires et des obligatai.L'a res de la Société.

Ils ont du avoir bien considéré les consé de goences de leur entrée dans l'administration de la Société, conséquences dont la première et me la plus légitime sera celle d'inspirer à tous les intéressés la plus absolue confiance dans l'averec nir de l'exploitation. Cette confiance, que nous partageons d'ailleurs, les nouveabx administratours sont en train de la justifier complète al ment. La décision qu'ils viennent de prendre, d'acoord avec le gouvernement relative au transfert à ce dernier da réseau de voies

enco ferrées, 68t de nature à apporter à la Société les plus grands ayantages. D'an côté, rem le dégrèvement de cent mille livres environ de frais annuels que comportait l'entretien des ateliers et de la voie et le transport des matiè. res brute et travaillée; de l'aatre, la pénétra
larg tion de la canne dans les hodds de la HauteEgypto que la cession des chemins de fer va réaliser, 888urent à la nouvelle administration reste les meillears débuts.
tion: D'autre part, l'adjonction aux ingénienre

5 8b gouvernementaux chargés d'opérer le transfert. I debo d'Ismaïl pacha Sirry, inspecteur général da tare cercle des projets d'irrigation, ainsi que la dé- Les cision de la Société Khediviale d'Agriculture de faire de la canne à sucre l'objet de ses éto. No des et de ses propositions au même titre que date le coton, montrent que le gouvernement est "I
disposés se servir de tous les moyens qui sont à mais • 8a disposition pour répandre et protéger la cul. tare de la canne à sucre dans la Haute Egypte. feate
Une bonne administraticn et l'application de ment procédés plas rationnels dans la caltare et dans mais • l'indastrie sucrière feront le reste. Pour cela, le cette

choix de l'administrateur délégué et du direcan n teur général, ainsi que la décision des non-lquel veaux administrateurs qui consiste à appoyer nom joarnellement de leurs conseils l'action des ordin deux premiers sont d'excellent angore. catte

Certes, le passage de la crise d'hier à proch la prospérite de demain ne sera pas l'auvre 'éch de quelques mois. Les deux campagnes pro- | direct chaines sont déjà en quelques sorte compro-seura miseg. Ce n'est que dans trois ans que l'action biệpfaisante de la nouvelle administration en 19 pourra donner des résultats. D'ici là, il faut doit a attendre patiemment et se garder avec pruments dence, a'ussi bien des illusions faciles que des l'auto découragements sabits.

Nous détachons d'ane lettre de Londre, en date du 13 Join, les lignes suivantes: EL "La situation monétaire tend à se détendre,

mais c'est peut-être là an effet momentané. Cortes, l'aisance revient peu à peu et se mani. feste particulièrement par un certain relève. ment de la réserve de la Banque d'Angleterre; mais encore re faut-il pas perdre de vue que cette réserve doit être promptement ramenée à

19 on niveau notablement supérieur à celui auquel elle est actaellement. En effet, si les phé. nomènes économiques qui se prodaisent ordinairement en Jaillet se renon vellent catte année, la Banque devra dès le mois ini prochain, lever EDS vannes pour laisser s'échapper de l'or sollicité dans diverses | directions. Cette perspective n'a rien de raBegrant avec une réserve qui est inférieure de £4 millions à celle existant en pareille époque en 1905. De plus, étant donné que la Banque doit se båter d'augmenter ses approvisionnements en vue de faire face aux éventaalités de l'automne, il n'y pas lieu de compter sur un abairsement du taux d'escompte de sa part, C'est à ce rosserrement prévu de l'argent qu'il faut principalement attribuer la mauvaise tenue de la Bourse."

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Com. pagnie da Canal de Suez tenue le 12 Juin à Parie, a approuvé les comptes de 1905 et fixé le dividende de cet exercice à Pre. 151,33 par action, y compris l'intérêt statataire de 25 franse.
Elle a, de plag, autorisé le conseil d'adminis. Itration & porter de 25 à 50 millions l'emprunt
pour travaux d'amélioration voté par l'assemblée da 4 Juin 1903.

div.head: AMERICAN SOCIALISM.
div.p: THE MEAT SCANDALS.
The first qnestion that everyone, English or SAR American, asks on reading Tha Jangle" is,
"Are these things trae ? Is it sociological fact we are dealing with here, or novelist's fiction, or the partisanship and distortions of a proselytising Socialist ?" Many men who know
Mr. Sinclair hold the unanimous conviction 21. that any assertion to which he has pat bis acting
name may be aocepted 88 a tact without farther rived inquiry. That is the repatation be enjoys
among those who have worked with him in - the
the investigation of social and indastrial proineff
blems. The book itself is written with fow or
none of the artifices of more sensationalism. been
The hotesty of Mr. Sinclair's mind impre 3888 uter)
itself at once. That he has the faculty of
clear-sightedness and the literary power of 21.
reproducing what he sees is also very evident, e OC- and a certain niggardliness of the imaginatopoltion strengthens ope's faith in his veracity.
but Moreover, before venturing to allow their med. Dame to appear opon its title-page his Ameri.

the can publishers go bmitted The Jungle" to & at of lawyer, who oondacted an independent investi. de is gation into its statements. Nothing has happenosely led since it came out to shake Mr. Sinclair's positadttion in & single particolar. The packera bave (R.) met his exposares with personal abuse and
generalised denials. He, on the contrary, bas the reiterated all his charges and bas battressed all no except one-& mere matter of detail in which
he admits having been mistakon-with official and comolative evidence. It seems probable,
indeed, that ha bag onder-stated rather than LE.
over-stated his case. The Commissioners whom Mr. Roosevelt immediately appointed to inquire
into his allegations have fornished a report that ned the President hesitated long before publishing ard. for fear lest the horror and anger it would
aroase might override ganity and strike the fal. beef indagtry dead. That scarcely look3 88
though the author of "Th. Jangle" had exaggarated or distorted the ghastly facts.
But let 08 bear what Mr. Sinclair himself has to say of his purpose and methods in writing |
the book. In the New York "Independent" for ern May 17 he answers his correspondents and critics
me "Vintend 'The Jangle," he saye, "to be an
to be exact and faithful picture of conditions as they spe ra. exist in Packingtown, Chicago. I mean it to be
the ed. true, not merely in substance, but in detail, or and in the smallest detail. It is as true as it
ext should be if it were not a work of fiction at all, I but a study by a sociologist ; it is so true that . students may go to it as they would to a work of reference."
sito VALIDITY. OF MR. SINCLAIR'S CLAIM.

not There is independent testimony to the validity of Mr. Sinclair's claim. Mr. Robert Hanter, wbo, as his book "Poverty" showg, is an investigator of social economics not less expert, conscientious, and level-beaded than Mr. Booth, or Mr. Beebohm Ruwộtree, wrote to the author
rood of "The Jangle" : "Having lived for three
It is years in that hell called the Chicago stock
diti yards, I can say that you have given a fall and
wor true piotare of the lifa in that commanity."
unei Even more emphatio is the opinion of a clergy.
volt man who for three years bad been pastor of The Mr. Armour's own church in Chicago : "It seems to me," he wrote, "that I hava a
ager certain concreta right to spork, for in some ways I have been closer to the sheer devilry
sha of the thing than even your.elf. Men will say|
pain that you have overdrawn the thing ; it is pot
the 80. Words utterly fail and break down in the attempt to tell the story. Terrible as is 'The Jangle,' it falls far short of the awfal reality."
in so After this there will hardly be much questioning either of the essential or of the actual and verbal troth of Mr. Sinclair's narrative. It has to be taken as a literal and sober record of
tarn: the conditions onder which a great indastry is prosecuted, and those who are engaged in it:
(in Sc live in the present year of grace and in the
light second greatest city of a land that believes
world itself without a peor on earth. So taken it
vice, becomes at once, in the Carlylean phrase,
is vel significant of much. The adventures of this Lithuanian family in the Chicago stock yards
Sinol are 80 set forth as to be an epitome of nearly
Socia all the ille, social, economic, industrial, and
ingh political, of American civilisation. The book
fix at is frightfully, loathsomely typical. To many goggeative phases of it, perhaps to its deter

tical minating purpose and basio moral, the publio will be blind. But to the sensational and more or less superficial incidente related in it no blindness is possible. The American people home have seʻzed upon them with an almost exclusive an
anyw intensity. Nor can one blame them. There can be nothing more vital to a meat-eating
nervo dation than the conditions under which its chief article of food is prepared for the market for th Chicago is the principal slaughter-houee, not plove only for the American Union but for the
Amer world. Six firms, all of which have their
"years headquarters there, form a trust that dominates
relati the beef industry. The trust kills about half
to a b of all the cattle slaughtered in the United States. It supplies New York with about
would geventy-five per cent. of its beef, Boston with
eletic more than eighty five per cent., Philadelphia
neare with about sixty per cent., aud other leading cities in the East with from fifty to ninety per Amer cent. ; while its by-produota) and its canned
And ! goods of every description travel to the ends of
writer the earth. Nothing, theretoro, could be better
Mr. calculated to produce a world wide shook than
Social the assertion and the proof that the Chicago
the Atock yards are ron in ways that set all the
Ассов в laws of hygiene, sanitation, and decency at
millio defiance.
that & GOVERNMENT INSPECTORS.

It is nothing less than this that is estab- but t liabod by "The Jungle" and by the report of destin Mr. Roosevelt's Commissioners. The revolting | greater details of the exposure bøve already been mona

sufficiently advertised, and there is no need to retail them again. Mr. Sinclair spares his readers as little as he spares the packers, passing from one abomination to another with a quiet and terrible precision that by its very absence of theatricality almost compele belief. But the more than criminal practices which be lays bare raise other issues besides those of public health—1880es that vitally concern the administrative methods of the American Government in its dealing with these hoge indastrial corporations. Where, one asks are the Government, the State, and the municipal inspectors? How is it they have allowed such iniquities to grow up ander their very eyes ? Mr. Sinclair angwers that question only partially and indirectly, but what he says is
illuminating. "The people of Chicago," be I writeg, "Baw the Government inspectors in

Packingtown, and they all took that to mean log that they were protected from diseased meat; they did not anderstand that these hundred and sixty-three inspectors had been appointed at the request of the packers, and that they were paid by the United States Government to certify that all diseased meat was kept in the State. They had no anthority beyond that ; for the inspection of meat to be sold in the ab city and State the whole force in Packingtown consisted of three honohmon of the looal poli. tical machine." That does not, however, tell the whole story. With the cor flict between national, State; and local authority, with the atter inability of the inspectors, even if every one of them did his daty, to examine with any thoroughneas the 152,009 cattle which are sometimes delivered at the stockyards in
scal & single day, and 40,000 or 50,000 which A-e a ni slaughtered there every day; with a total
But lack of any fixed standard of condemna

reco tion; with the prevalence of the spirit of cut "graft" and the immunity with which the packers (who are wealthy and on the spot, while the Government is distant and niggardly) are able to foster it to their own advantage ;
han with the ridicalons 8880 with which the
"ina Government stamp of approval or tag of con
mon demnation can be imitated or removed ; and
of A with 'politios" and jobbery playing their part
desc in every appointment-it is scarcely too much
Indi to say that the system of Government in.
the 2 spectorship is from the national standpoint an
laite absolate faroe. To this there is one exception
well meat (not canned goods) intended for export
grow to Europe is rigorously and scientifically in
thiar spected. "The foreigner," said the Chicago
have municipal bacteriologist a few weeks ago, "gets
have the very best, for be demands it, and has
Bat! experts to see that he gets it. The inter-State trade gets the next grade. What is left goes ant into the Chicago market. Bad meat, like a bad character, quickly loses its identity in a great

of al city." Another expert has summed up the scalp situation by saying that "faderal inspection is 800 ! nothing more than a shrewd advertising Boheme corp saggested to the packers several years ago, whon several Earopean countries forbade the
witho exportation to them of triobinal-infacted pork" I bosc
Did POLITICAL AND SOCIAL A BUSES.

slaves "The Jungle" is more than a photographic the è record of mechanical horrors in the stockyards. boye, It is a hamun and appalling stody of the con- scalp ditions andar which the employees live and ment work, conditions that in their unrelieved and any anendurable misery are infinitely more re- let co volting than the dootoring of diseased meat. Iin the The straggles of thia Lithuanian family, 874. how they are mercilessly flyeced by a house l term agent in the employ of a political boss and lipg 'stack" with a tumble-down and insanitary | mand shanty, of which nothing is now but the hatt

paint on the boards outside ; how they toil in deali I the stockyards to gupport the orashing burden of of rent and interest; their agonising suffering. The in summer and winter when the plants shat were down or ran on half time ; how the husband They dezoonds to the horrors of the fertilising taoto. I colle ry; how one child is drowned in the street baron and another eaten by rats; how the husband |

man turns tramp, thief, thaug, political "heeler," lind strike-breaker, and altimately finds redemption lengt Tin Socialism--all this, with its manifold side by ? lights on the realities of the Chicago under long. world of labour, politics, "graft," orime, and nim vice, makes ap a true and terrible tale. And it in lo is very clear that this was the real object Mr. to Sinclair had in view. He wrote not to make ber : Amorioang vegetarians, but to make them
akip Socialiste, lees to reveal the filth of the pack ing ho0808 and the tricks of the trade than to fix attention on the far graver social and polidae tical abuses that follow in the wake of such an
soal organisation as the Beef Trust. Socialism's Growing POWER.
ther There is in American industrialism an in-|
An humanity such as can hardly be paralleled
forg anywhere outside of the Congo Free State.

esta The "speeding-ap" of workmen till they are tool nervous and physical wrecke ; the lack of any feeling of responsibility on the part of Capital for the bealth, safety and comfort of its om. In ployees-in all matters of factory Jegislation

tort America is pretty much where we were forty years ago and the rathlees redaction of the relations between omployers and employed to a basis of baro greed explain by themselves the the growing power of American Socialism. It prid would not be sorprising it at the Presidential l two eletion two years horce the Socialists poll nearer two million than one million votes,
soal The ablest and most earnest minds of young America are rapidly turning towards them. And besides a small but brilliant group of BCA

mer writera-many of whom, like Mr. Sinclair and Mr. Jack London, are able to popularise Socialism through the invaluable medium of Dan the novel - they are constantly receiving baw accessiong from the ranks of the younger not millionaire. It is, of course, too much to say that Socialism as yet shows signs of becoming the religion of the American working man, but that it is already a great power and destined to become & greater, it not the pec greatest, no oloso observer of American phonomena can doubt for a moment.

div.head: SCALPING.
div.p: A writer in "Scribner's Magazine" assails & mean legend dear to schoolboys. He declares that meat;
the Apachés never scalped & foe, citing the dred
evidence of white men who had passed their Ented | lives among them. In fact, they have and they
always had such a horror of dead bodies that nt to
they will.not touch the remains of a friend 2 the
killed in battle, leaving the women to bury hat;
him. Will these deplorable person who go the about destroying our cherished fancies 'never
stay their sacrilogious hands ? If Apachés did poli
not scalp they were exceptions to the role, not tell among "Redokins" only. A carefal sarvey of
piankind would show that the practice was the common once in Asia and Earope ; negro very
"wool" does not make a handsome trophy, or any
it might have prevailed in Africa also. We
have forgotten that our excellent forefathers in scalped-and so systematically that thay had
a name for the process and also for its result. telBut some of as still read Herodotus and they
recollect that the Scythians "made a circalar cut round the ears of a dead enemy, and then, taking hold of the skin, scraped off the flash with the rib of an ox (!), softened the skin
with thair hands, and used it 89 & napkin, or ge;
hang it on their bridles" ; if they had enoogh, The "made cloaks of them." Here is another argaonment for those who arge that the aborigines

of America came from Asia ; for the method I described is exactly that in use among Rod Indians, and if the scalps were not utilised in the same way, it must be recollected that the latter had no horses. Besides, Pasbion might well change in such a long migration. But it grows more and more probable that the Soythians of Herodotas were Teutong. They may have carried th y usage to Earope or they may have shared it with their Earopean kinsfolk. Bot Ronan says that the Semitic Aseyriang and Babylonians scalped. Doubtless he had anthority for the assertion.

Herbert Spencer gaggested that the custom of shaving the heads of slavas arose from scalping. In the course of ages mon osme to see that a captive is more useful than a corpse, and that his hair may be equally or- | namental, bat for the name of the thing, without the skin attached. Bat if this view be sound, scalping must have bean universal, Did any race of men omit to orop their
slaves, excepting, of course, the Romans of|I in the decadence, who loved to have bandsome ( 84 8. boys, with long hair, to wait upon them?
Scalping, "decalvere," is named as & punishd'ment in the Visigoth Code, and if there be
any doubt of its meaning we have "uapillos
et catom detrahere," aecribed to the Francs Ghe t. J in the Aonals of Falda. This was 80 late as 7, 874. Guizot says briefly that the Anglo-Saxon
torm for the operation was "hettinad," qaot-1 ing Adelon's "Histoire ancienne des Alle- 00 mands." The scalp itself, bowover, was called T

hatterell." An old Visitation of Cumberland, dealing with the arms of De Boyvil, Lord of Millam, tells a legend to the purpose. The Baron of Egremont and big brother were captured by Paynim in the Holy Land.
They allowed the former to go home and | collect ransom for botb. Bat, once more in t baronial splendour at Egremont, the gentle
man forgot his obligation. The brother left in daranoo vile passed a very bad time. At
length the misoreants tied him up to a beam - by his hair, which had grown prodigiously

long, and left him to starve. But the Pay. Xi nim Prince's daughter bad fallen desperately in love with the prisoner. She camo secretly to release him, but the canding knots defied | W ber; in despair, at length, she out into the li skin, and the weight of the youth's body 1 "rent away the rest." Clever leeches employed list
by the maiden brought him round, and in - due time he returned, carrying his severed a

Boals, to Egremont. The Baron was entertaining the nobility and gentry of the neighbourhood when the familiar notes of his brother's horn ontside the castle startled him. An oppleasant scene followed, until, to secure forgiveness, the Baron made over this fine estate of Millam. Therefore the young lord
d'o took for his arms a Horn and a "Hatterell,"
dive which were still borne by his descendante.. We ask in vain what booame of the lady. In the absence of information it is saddening to recall that men were deceivers ever.
The Danes algo practised scalping under the name of "behaettie"; bat Thrupp onderstands
TH the description to mean that "a obampion". prided himself on effecting the operation in two outs—
& m: Redskin did it in one by all accounts. Edgar's law punished thieves by bedr scalping ; 80 did Canuto's. Thus the hero o
stati practices of war degenerate. Bat Earl Godwin TE scalped a large proportion of the six hundred with
unde men he took with the Atheling Alfred-"Never

effice was bloodier deed done in the land since the Danes came," says the Saxon Chronicle. We bave seen that the word "hatterell" was still not unfamiliar in the sixteenth century, and the proceeding also was not quite forgotten, perhaps, in 1854 On the terrible day of St. Sobolastics in that year Oxford students soalped the students they caught, "viz.," says Anthony à Wood, "all the skin as far as the tonadre went these diabolio imps flayed off." om

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
